name.text: Q1. Service Level vs Fill Rate

questiontext.text: Which situation will reduce Service Level but may leave Fill Rate almost unchanged?

answer.text: Missing a large demand spike on a single day

feedback.text: Incorrect. A large missed spike will hurt Fill Rate significantly, not leave it almost unchanged.

answer.text: Fulfilling all demand but only after long delays

feedback.text: Incorrect. With long delays, Fill Rate can still be high, but this is not about a low-demand stockout day.

answer.text: Running out of stock on a low-demand day

feedback.text: Correct. Service Level is day-based, so any zero-stock day reduces SL, even if the demand on that day is low.

answer.text: Supplier delivering early and increasing on-hand inventory

feedback.text: Incorrect. Early delivery raises on-hand inventory and does not directly reduce Service Level.

name.text: Q2. Stockout root cause: demand vs supplier

questiontext.text: A stockout occurred on a day where demand was far above mean plus standard deviation, while lead time remained normal. What is the most likely root cause?

answer.text: Late supplier

feedback.text: Incorrect. Lead time is normal, so a late supplier is not the main driver of this stockout.

answer.text: Demand spike

feedback.text: Correct. Demand far above mean plus standard deviation with normal lead time indicates a demand-driven stockout.

answer.text: Both demand spike and late supplier

feedback.text: Incorrect. The scenario states that lead time remained normal, so the supplier is not late.

answer.text: Insufficient dataset quality

feedback.text: Incorrect. The stockout is best explained by an extreme demand spike rather than a data quality issue.

questiontext.text: If On-Hand Inventory is 480 units and recent average daily demand is 80 units, how many days of cover remain?

answer.text: 4 days

feedback.text: Incorrect. Days of cover is On-Hand divided by average daily demand: 480 divided by 80 is not 4.

answer.text: 5 days

feedback.text: Incorrect. 480 units at 80 units per day would last longer than 5 days.

answer.text: 6 days

feedback.text: Correct. Days of cover = On-Hand divided by average daily demand = 480 divided by 80 = 6 days.

answer.text: 7 days

feedback.text: Incorrect. You are overestimating; 480 divided by 80 gives 6 days, not 7.

questiontext.text: Which change will increase Safety Stock the most, assuming all else equal?

answer.text: Reducing the service target (lower z-score)

feedback.text: Incorrect. Lowering the service target reduces the z-score and therefore lowers Safety Stock.

answer.text: Lowering daily demand volatility (lower sigma)

feedback.text: Incorrect. Lower volatility (lower sigma) decreases Safety Stock, it does not increase it.

answer.text: Increasing supplier lead time from 4 to 9 days

feedback.text: Correct. Safety Stock SS equals z times sigma times square root of L; increasing lead time L from 4 to 9 strongly increases SS.

answer.text: Keeping sigma and L constant but increasing receipt quantity

feedback.text: Incorrect. Receipt quantity does not directly enter the standard Safety Stock formula.

questiontext.text: You compute a Reorder Point (ROP) of 460 units. Current Inventory Position (On-Hand plus On-Order minus Backorders) is 390 units. What should happen next?

answer.text: No action; inventory is above the threshold

feedback.text: Incorrect. Inventory Position is below the ROP, so the threshold has already been crossed.

answer.text: Increase safety stock first, then decide

feedback.text: Incorrect. The ROP has already been crossed; you should trigger replenishment immediately.

answer.text: Place a replenishment order now

feedback.text: Correct. When Inventory Position falls below the Reorder Point, replenishment must be triggered immediately.

answer.text: Reduce demand temporarily to avoid stockouts

feedback.text: Incorrect. The correct control action in an ROP system is to place an order, not to artificially reduce demand.
